text: [Music]
I don't know of anybody who's really a

it's got um it's it's strophic in nature
it's uh it's got parallelism so we know
it's poetry and so you read it as poetry
you don't take it literally when when
David says the stars came and fought
against the Assyrians you know we know
that that's poetry then there are some
places like Genesis 1 chapter 1 uh like
the Book of Ecclesiastes like a couple
there's a couple places in the Bible
where the genre is not easy to discern
and where people are going to be arguing
about whether you take that literally or
not obviously Genesis 1 has a big impact
on how you understand Evolution and so
forth so uh I would consider myself a a
person who believes in the full
authority of the Bible and yet even if
you believe that there's room for debate
about what parts of the Bible you take
literally and not yet when somebody says
are you a Bible literalist they probably
uh will still think I am a biblical
literalist because I Think Jesus
actually rose from the dead and if some

with it for example though Genesis 2 and
3 I think are written you might say as
historical Pros narrative whereas
Genesis 1 is not so you know I would
actually personally I would say I don't
take Genesis 1 literally I actually do
take the talking snake
literally that's why I and there's
people around me who have this same view
of the Bible who would draw the line on
the other side of the snake and there's
other people who would draw it all the
way at the beginning and say no you have
to take Genesis 1 literally so there and
these are all this is all within the
fraternity and the sorority it might say
of people who believe that you have to
take the Bible as the full authoritative
word of God so I do think Bill Maher is
uh uh Missing the the Spectrum it's a
little bit like if you say to a person
of a particular race all you people look
alike that's awfully insulting and for
Bill Maher to look at say Evangelical
Christians and say all you people are
literalist is just as
insulting the essence of the model is in
the book The Prodigal God because the
Prodigal God is about the famous story
in Luke 15 that Jesus tells uh that is
usually called the parable of the
prodigal son if you read it fully it's
actually about two sons one is the
younger brother who goes off and
squanders his uh his money on
prostitutes and the other is the elder
brother who stays home and obeys the
father and what I look at that as is um
the younger brother symbolizing you
might say the secular person who says I
can live any way I want the elder
brother symbolizing the religious person
who's very moralistic and
self-righteous and both being uh
alienated from the father and that's
Jesus way of saying these are both wrong
so that is that's a great way to explain
in one simple uh with one simple
narrative how our model differs um I
think most people tend to say well
there's you can go off and live your way
or else you can live God's way and
that's the two approaches and a lot of
secular people say fine I've seen the
God's way thing it's filled with
moralism self-righteousness and
oppression I'm going to go and make up
my own mind as to how to live and a lot
of Believers think that that there's
only two ways and I'm trying to show
that there's three and there's there's
another approach
